In case no one noticed, the biggest difference (besides the 1982 poll, which shouldn't be part of this discussion since it did not offer a response for both spending cuts and tax increases) is between the March 2010 and the September 2011 polls.

In March 2010, 42% wanted a combination of spending cuts and tax increases. In September 2011, 71% wanted combination.

The figures for 1988 and 2010 seem to argue against any big change in attitudes. In May 1988, 47% wanted spending cuts, while 39% wanted a combination of spending cuts and tax increases. In March 2010 42% wanted a combination of taxes and cuts, while 49% wanted only spending cuts.

In the 1980s it went down to 50%. Today it's 35%. So you are wrong about a certain generation. Baby boomers paid more in tax than you (assuming you're not a crotchety 75 year old who is angry about the taxes he/she paid).

When it comes to public access to and use of spatial data, governments everywhere and at all levels are now grappling with the enormous cultural shift required to engage the power of public participation. While crisis mappers, random hackers of kindness et. al. seemingly in their own world, merrily push the envelope to see where it gives. The problem is that when it comes to disaster response and preparedness neither the public sector nor the public can be of much help without each other.

The much ballyhooed crowd-sourced information after the Haitian earthquake sent many on wild goose chases, and multiple responses to the same needs tweeted and retweeted endlessly. (Just as two gunshots into the air after Hurricane Katrina were magnified into a relentless volley of bullets from all quarters). And, as usual, some needs remained overlooked. The actual number of actionable and actioned messages was just enough to constitute a learning experience.

Technical issues aside, the two biggest challenges to crowd-sourcing reliable and actionable post-disaster information are the need for public education prior to a disaster on how and what to communication. And the the need to organize volunteer commitment ahead of time to process information at the enormous scale that a city the size of Istanbul or Los Angeles would generate.

It will be fascinating to see whether Turkish authorities can learn to abide the realities of the digital world, and the pro-social instincts of the very social-media savvy young population to play a role in this... or whether they will continue to wield the heavy hand of authority that regularly blocks access to all of YouTube because of one offending video in cyberspace.

Great article Andrew. The Soviet military maps actually get down to 1:50,000 for the whole country and 1:10,000 for cities. http://www.omnimap.com/catalog/int/turkey.htm. Not a bad solution, and probably pretty accurate. Maybe that helps explain Enver Pasa's devastating loss...

When in former Yugoslavia, for hiking I found some US government topo maps that were at the 1:25,000 level and pretty accurate in both contours and landmarks. They had them for pretty much every country in the world, including Turkey. Problem is, I have not been able to locate the source since and I gave the maps away when I left so don't have any way to track them now. It was hard to find the source at the time, and now it seems to be irretrievably buried in Google spam.

I visited Turkey about four years ago, including a road trip from Kusadasi (near Izmir), through Gallipoli, to Istanbul. Tourist maps were readily available for all larger towns, and in great detail for Istanbul, no different from anywhere else. Finding detailed roadmaps was more complicated. But, as always outside the U.S., Michelin came to the rescue with maps that would zoom to virtually any scale I wanted. The Turkish government may be leery (paranoid?) about giving away too much information but they can’t stop digital progress.

Mr. Charlap,

It seems that we really don't "speak the same language" and, frankly, I doubt we ever will. Nevertheless, here's one last try:

You wrote:

"You end with "Clearly, acting for the general welfare is not a separate and distinct power." But

Butler says, "

The clause confers a power separate and distinct from those later enumerated [,] is not restricted in meaning by the grant of them" Now how do you reconcile these two statement.?

When Butler refers to "the clause" he is not referring to the "power to act in the general welfare" (there is no such separate power). He is referring to the power to tax and spend. The "general welfare" language is contained in the recitation of the power to tax and spend and, as I've tried to explain to you repeatedly, it actually was intended to limit that power. As I explained in the earlier comment, Butler's intent was that the separate power to tax and spend is not itself limited by the other enumerated power such as, for example, the power to raise an army.

You seem to be cutting and pasting without having much understanding of the text you are selectively appropriating from original sources. Perhaps you would find it easier to consult a secondary source such as Wikipedia which has a good general discussion of the issue. That discussion begins with: “The United States Constitution contains two references to "the General Welfare", one occurring in the Preamble and the other in the Taxing and Spending Clause. It is only the latter that is referred to as the "General Welfare Clause" of this document. These clauses in the U.S. Constitution are exceptions to the typical use of a general welfare clause, and are not considered grants of a general legislative power to the federal government[2] as the U.S. Supreme Court has held:…”

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/General_Welfare_clause

I hope you find this useful.

The key to the Republican primary in 2012 is that Romney knows he can't get a majority of votes outright in most states against any remotely teabagger-pleasing opposition. He therefore has two paths to victory.
1. Win the early states decisively and have no significant opposition by the time Super Tuesday rolls around. This one seems like a long shot. He's not well-liked in any of the early states except New Hampshire, and anything in NH but an overwhelming victory would be viewed as a sign of weakness anyhow.
2. Keep at least two far-right rivals in the race until April, splitting the far-right vote and getting to the winner-take-all states with around a third of the total delegates thus far (about half of the total will have been decided by then), and then try to win the vast majority of the winner-take-all states by 40-30-30 split decisions. He still might not be able to get enough delegates to win outright, but he might get enough that one defection by another candidate could put him over the top.

What really hurts Romney is that unlike in 2008, he can't score a quick knockout blow with early states. With proportional representation in place, the farthest-back candidates (Bachmann, Frothymixture, Roemer, Johnson, Huntsman) will probably drop out fairly early, leaving it to Gingrich (or another flavor-of-the-month) plus Perry (whose resources mean he won't give up easily) and Paul (who just doesn't care). Without a heavily split far-right field, Romney's path to the nomination becomes problematic, to say the least, because he just can't accumulate enough delegates early to readily win once it gets to winner-take-all.

There is an extremely important factor missing here, and that is context:

What was the question asked by these polls? I don't think the question was "do you favor cutting spending or raising *your* taxes. No, the likely question was simply "do you favor cutting spending or raising taxes".

Historically, I think, such a generic question would have been interpreted by those taking part of the poll to mean the former---that is, if I answer that I favor raising taxes that would mean *my* taxes will be raised. That would have been the general understanding in earlier times, in the context of the debate that would have been taking place then.

Today, however, (this would be relevant to the last two polls) 99 percent of the population is being led to believe that by favoring the rise of taxes it means someone else will suffer the burden of that tax rise (that is, the top 1 percent). Is it any surprise that a poll that is interpreted as asking, in effect, whether one's own tax should be increased would have a lower percentage favoring tax increases that a poll that in effect asks whether someone else's tax should be increased?

Violence in humans has declined due to, in large part, social selection -- the most powerful mechanism of natural selection operating on socialized humans. Just as domesticated dog docility has gradually replaced wild dog ferocity, as a result of selective breeding and destruction of the unwanted, human society's law & order institutions has reduced the prevalence of genes predisposing humans to anti-social acts of violence by destroying the carriers of such genes on the gallows or putting them in conditions unfavorable to procreation.

If the above hypothesis is correct, two predictions can be made:

1. Socially organized violence -- war, state brutality, religious persecution -- presumably emerging from a different set of emotions hence different genes, should not have declined. Thus, 20th century wars need not be considered a fluke; rather, war violence should be accounted for in a class by itself.

2. If the current soft treatment of hard criminality in the West continues unabated, the "mean gene" would by necessity eventually rebound and we should expect criminal violence to surge in the coming generations to prehistorical levels. That is, if alternative cultures, better adapted to long-term survival, would not take over and restore the good-old primitive social defenses.

People who chose not to have their kids vaccinated think that they're making a decision only for those kids.  But they are also making that decision for a lot of other people, like my sister who has an autoimmune disorder and will be immuno-compromised for the rest of her life, or my little nephew who was too young for vaccines once upon a time.  While I get that people make decisions based on their tactile experiences (which are often very much in contrast to science, but we're hardwired to weight our own experiences far more than the population's as a whole), I still think that it is incredibly hubristic to make decisions for other people given the overwhelming evidence in favor of vaccines.  My opinion is that much better science education is needed in this country so that people learn how to weigh risks, much better history education is needed so people realize why there was such a desperate search for effective vaccines in the first place, and much better current-events education is needed so that people realize that there are a lot of people who know first-hand why vaccines are necessary.
